A resting time allows sauces to thicken while the spices mellow and the flavors begin to meld together. When making Sriracha, we found that allowing the hot sauce to age for 24 hours in the refrigerator helped the sauce to take on a much more complex flavor profile. For the best texture and most balanced flavor, it’s necessary to make Dijon mustard at least five days before use. Although it may be tempting to dig into these condiments immediately after making them, patience will be rewarded.

Chow-Chow

CHOW-CHOW

PREP 25 minutes

SALT 3 hours

COOK 25 minutes

PROCESS 10–25 minutes

YIELD four 1-cup jars

WHY THIS RECIPE WORKS Chow-chow is a sweet green tomato relish packed with mustard and celery seeds. There are countless regional variations, some with cauliflower, others with cabbage or peppers. While Pennsylvania chow-chow is sweeter, we liked the Southern take with a kick to balance the syrupy juices in this relish. We chose a combination of jalapeño and cayenne for heat. Bell peppers provided a mild fruitiness, and cabbage lent a crispness. We found that using a food processor gave us the perfect size pieces. Salting the vegetables for 3 hours pulled out any excess moisture. Our other pickle relish recipes often squeeze the salted vegetables out with a towel to remove any excess moisture. We found this to be too rough with the cabbage; it drew too much liquid from the tomatoes, leaving nothing behind to make a juicy brine. We waited to add the vegetables to the brine until it was off the heat; this kept the cabbage crisp and the peppers and tomatoes firm.

3 green tomatoes, cored and chopped coarse

1 cup coarsely chopped green cabbage

1 cup coarsely chopped green bell pepper

½ cup coarsely chopped red bell pepper

½ cup coarsely chopped onion

1 jalapeño chile, stemmed, seeded, and coarsely chopped

1½ tablespoons canning and pickling salt

½ cup distilled white vinegar

½ cup sugar

1¼ teaspoons yellow mustard seeds

½ teaspoon celery seeds

¼ teaspoon turmeric

¼ teaspoon cayenne pepper

1. Combine tomatoes, cabbage, bell peppers, onion, and jalapeño in bowl. Working in 3 batches, pulse vegetables in food processor until pieces measure ¼ to ½ inch, 4 to 6 pulses; transfer to separate bowl. Stir in salt, cover, and refrigerate for 3 hours.

2. Set canning rack in large pot, place four 1-cup jars in rack, and add water to cover by 1 inch. Bring to simmer over medium-high heat, then turn off heat and cover to keep hot.

3. Transfer vegetables to colander and let drain for 20 minutes. Bring vinegar, sugar, mustard seeds, celery seeds, turmeric, and cayenne to boil in large saucepan over high heat. Reduce to simmer and cook until slightly thickened, about 5 minutes. Off heat, stir in drained vegetables.

4. Place dish towel flat on counter. Using jar lifter, remove jars from pot, draining water back into pot. Place jars upside down on towel and let dry for 1 minute. Using funnel and ladle, portion relish into hot jars, leaving ½ inch headspace. Slide wooden skewer along inside of jar, pressing slightly on relish, to remove air bubbles.

5a. For short-term storage: Let relish cool to room temperature. Cover, refrigerate, and serve. (Relish can be refrigerated for at least 6 months.)

5b. For long-term storage: While jars are hot, wipe rims clean, add lids, and screw on rings until fingertip-tight; do not overtighten. Return pot of water with canning rack to boil. Lower jars into water, cover, bring water back to boil, then start timer. Cooking time will depend on your altitude: Boil 10 minutes for up to 1,000 feet, 15 minutes for 1,001 to 3,000 feet, 20 minutes for 3,001 to 6,000 feet, and 25 minutes for 6,001 to 8,000 feet. Turn off heat and let jars sit in pot for 5 minutes. Remove jars from pot and let cool for 24 hours. Remove rings, check seal, and clean rims. (Sealed jars can be stored for up to 1 year.)

DOUBLE IT

Double all ingredients. Pulse vegetables in 6 batches. Increase brine simmering time in step 3 to about 8 minutes.

Spicy Red Pepper Relish

SPICY RED PEPPER RELISH

PREP 25 minutes

COOK 25 minutes

PROCESS 10–25 minutes

YIELD four 1-cup jars

WHY THIS RECIPE WORKS Our red pepper relish has the perfect balance of sweetness and spice. To start, we opted for a combination of red bell peppers and jalapeños; red bell peppers have a natural sweetness, which complements the fiery bite of green jalapeños. We first used a 1:1 ratio of bell peppers to jalapeños along with a small amount of onion, which produced a far-too-spicy “mash” rather than a relish-like consistency, so we decided to scale down the amount of jalapeños for a more balanced relish. For added sweetness and acidity, we used equal amounts of white vinegar and sugar, which tempered the chile heat. Yellow mustard seeds added a mellow kick. The sweet and spicy notes of the relish melded after a quick simmer on the stovetop. Kosher salt can be substituted for the canning and pickling salt if desired; click here for more information.

5 red bell peppers, stemmed, seeded, and cut into 1-inch pieces

4 jalapeño chiles, stemmed, seeded, and cut into 1-inch pieces

1 small onion, chopped

6 garlic cloves, peeled

1 cup distilled white vinegar

1 cup sugar

2 teaspoons yellow mustard seeds

1½ teaspoons canning and pickling salt

1. Set canning rack in large pot, place four 1-cup jars in rack, and add water to cover by 1 inch. Bring to simmer over medium-high heat, then turn off heat and cover to keep hot.

2. Working in 2 batches, pulse bell peppers and jalapeños in food processor until coarsely chopped into ¼-inch pieces, 8 to 10 pulses; transfer to large bowl. Pulse onion and garlic in food processor until coarsely chopped into ¼-inch pieces, about 10 pulses; transfer to bowl with peppers.

3. Bring vinegar, sugar, mustard seeds, and salt to boil in Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Add vegetable mixture, reduce heat to medium, and simmer, stirring occasionally, until mixture has thickened, 15 to 18 minutes.

4. Place dish towel flat on counter. Using jar lifter, remove jars from pot, draining water back into pot. Place jars upside down on towel and let dry for 1 minute. Using funnel and ladle, portion relish into hot jars, leaving ½ inch headspace. Slide wooden skewer along inside of jar, pressing slightly on relish, to remove air bubbles.

5a. For short-term storage: Let relish cool to room temperature. Cover, refrigerate, and serve. (Relish can be refrigerated for up to 3 months; flavor will deepen over time.)

5b. For long-term storage: While jars are hot, wipe rims clean, add lids, and screw on rings until fingertip-tight; do not overtighten. Return pot of water with canning rack to boil. Lower jars into water, cover, bring water back to boil, then start timer. Cooking time will depend on your altitude: Boil 10 minutes for up to 1,000 feet, 15 minutes for 1,001 to 3,000 feet, 20 minutes for 3,001 to 6,000 feet, and 25 minutes for 6,001 to 8,000 feet. Turn off heat and let jars sit in pot for 5 minutes. Remove jars from pot and let cool for 24 hours. Remove rings, check seal, and clean rims. (Sealed jars can be stored for up to 1 year.)

DOUBLE IT

Double all ingredients. Pulse bell peppers and jalapeños in 3 batches, and pulse onions and garlic in 2 batches. Increase simmering time in step 3 to about 30 minutes.

SIMPLE HOT SAUCE

PREP 10 minutes

COOK 40 minutes

YIELD two cups

WHY THIS RECIPE WORKS We liked the idea of making our own hot sauce with a few well-chosen ingredients and a wallop of heat. We tried a few recipes that called for different varieties of chiles and cooking methods. We liked the clean flavor of habanero chiles, but their intense heat meant we couldn’t make a sauce using them alone. Tasters found uncooked sauces to be too raw, but liked qualities of boiled or roasted chiles. We began with our recipe by tempering the habaneros with red jalapeños. Rather than spending time roasting, we found it quicker to broil the peppers. To balance the heat, we added brown sugar, shallot, and garlic. Broiling the aromatics with the chiles took away their rawness. Our final challenge was the body of the sauce. Straining resulted in a thin sauce. We were also unwilling to add thickeners. As we researched other hot sauces, we found some that included carrots, an unexpected ingredient that gave the sauces body and sweetness. We added a chopped carrot to our next batch and found that the sauce had the perfect consistency. We left the seeds in the habaneros for their heat, but you can remove the seeds if you prefer a milder sauce. We were pleasantly surprised to find that this sauce tasted terrific right out of the blender. As it ages, the flavor matures a bit to become deeper. Although it’s tempting to store this sauce in plastic squeeze bottles, it’s better to store it in glass; the plastic can add off-flavors to the sauce as it sits. This hot sauce cannot be processed for long-term storage.

6 ounces red jalapeño or Fresno chiles

1 carrot, peeled and chopped

1 shallot, quartered

6 garlic cloves, peeled

2 ounces habanero chiles, stemmed

1 cup distilled white vinegar

2 tablespoons packed brown sugar

1 tablespoon salt

1. Adjust oven rack 8 inches from broiler element and heat broiler. Place jalapeños, carrot, shallot, and garlic on aluminum foil–lined baking sheet. Broil vegetables, turning jalapeños once, until jalapeños are black and blistered, 8 to 10 minutes.

2. Transfer jalapeños to bowl, cover with plastic wrap, and let sit for 10 minutes. Transfer remaining broiled vegetables to blender jar.

3. Remove and discard stems, seeds, and most of blackened skin from jalapeños, then transfer to blender jar with other vegetables. Add habaneros, vinegar, sugar, and salt, and process until smooth, about 1 minute.

4. Using funnel and ladle, portion hot sauce into 2-cup glass bottle. Let sauce cool to room temperature. Cover, refrigerate, and serve. (Sauce can be refrigerated for up to 3 months; flavor will deepen over time.)

To add a deeper flavor to the sauce, broil the jalapeños, carrot, shallot, and garlic until the jalapeños are blistered.

After briefly steaming the jalapeños, discard the stems and seeds and scrape off most of the blackened skin; leaving on a small amount of the blackened skin helps flavor the sauce.

Combine the roasted vegetables with the raw habaneros in the blender; the fresh flavor of the habaneros is what gives the sauce its heat. Add the vinegar, sugar, and salt to the blender and puree the sauce until it is very smooth and thickened, about 1 minute; do not strain the sauce.

Sriracha

SRIRACHA

PREP 15 minutes

COOK 45 minutes

AGE 1 day

YIELD 2 cups

WHY THIS RECIPE WORKS Sriracha is a fiery-red Thai-American hot sauce fondly known by its loyal followers as rooster sauce. Traditionally, Sriracha is made from a fermented chile mash, which is a process that can take over a week. We wanted a simple, streamlined version of rooster sauce we could make at home without the wait. Our first test consisted of processing chiles, vinegar, water, and garlic, along with a bit of sugar and salt. We cooked the mixture down to a ketchup-like consistency, which resulted in more of a chili-garlic paste than Sriracha. By adjusting the ratio of liquid to chiles and garlic, we were on track to a pourable hot sauce. We also swapped out white sugar in favor of brown; tasters preferred the richer, deeper notes of the dark brown sugar. We were getting closer to a more balanced hot sauce; however, we were missing the fermented flavor of the original. To achieve the unique flavor, we whisked 2 tablespoons of fish sauce into the chile mixture along with the sugar and salt. A quick simmer on the stovetop thickened the Sriracha and allowed the flavors to meld. Passing the finished product through a fine-mesh strainer gave us a smooth sauce. Finally, we found it crucial to let the sauce sit for a day to develop its flavor before serving. Although it’s tempting to store this sauce in plastic squeeze bottles, we found it better to store it in glass; the plastic can add off-flavors to the sauce as it sits. This Sriracha cannot be processed for long-term storage.

1½ pounds red jalapeño or Fresno chiles, stemmed

1¼ cups distilled white vinegar

¾ cup water

8 garlic cloves, peeled

2 tablespoons fish sauce

2 tablespoons packed dark brown sugar

5 teaspoons salt

1. Working in 2 batches, process jalapeños, vinegar, water, and garlic in blender until smooth, about 2 minutes. Transfer mixture to medium saucepan and whisk in fish sauce, sugar, and salt.

2. Bring mixture to boil over high heat, then reduce heat to medium-low and simmer, skimming any surface foam, until thickened, 18 to 20 minutes. Remove pan from heat and let cool for 5 minutes.

3. Process mixture in blender until smooth, about 1 minute. Strain Sriracha through fine-mesh strainer set over bowl, pressing on solids to extract as much sauce as possible.

4. Using funnel and ladle, portion Sriracha into 2-cup glass bottle. Let sauce cool to room temperature. Cover, refrigerate, and let flavors mature for at least 1 day before serving. (Sriracha can be refrigerated for up to 6 months; flavor will mature over time.)

Horseradish

HORSERADISH

TOTAL TIME 15 minutes

YIELD two 1-cup jars

WHY THIS RECIPE WORKS Homemade horseradish has a bright, spicy flavor that blows the store-bought alternative out of the water. Not only does making your own result in a fresher horseradish, but the signature heat of the homemade version also packs even more of a punch. We set out to create our own recipe for this piquant condiment and found the process to be surprisingly simple. Unlike store-bought brands, most of which call for a long list of ingredients, our recipe calls for only three: horseradish root, vinegar, and salt. We peeled and chopped the horseradish root into small enough pieces so they could be pulsed in a food processor and then processed to a pulpy consistency. Vinegar balances the spicy bite of fresh horseradish root. Throughout our testing tasters preferred cider vinegar, due to its sweet tang. We simply drizzled the vinegar into the food processor while blending the horseradish. A teaspoon of salt helped balance the acidic tang of the vinegar and intensify the spicy, earthy flavor of the horseradish. Kosher salt can be substituted for the canning and pickling salt if desired; click here for more information. This horseradish cannot be processed for long-term storage.

10 ounces horseradish root, peeled and chopped coarse (2 cups)

1 teaspoon canning and pickling salt

1 cup cider vinegar

1. Pulse horseradish and salt in food processor until coarsely chopped, about 15 pulses, scraping down bowl as needed. With processor running, slowly add vinegar until incorporated and mixture has pulp-like consistency, about 1 minute, scraping down bowl as necessary.

2. Using funnel and spoon, portion horseradish into two 1-cup jars. Serve. (Horseradish can be refrigerated for up to 3 weeks; flavor will deepen over time.)

CREAMY HORSERADISH

Lightly squeeze excess liquid from ½ cup prepared horseradish then transfer to small bowl. Stir in ¼ cup mayonnaise, ¼ teaspoon pepper, and ⅛ teaspoon salt. Serve. (Makes ½ cup. Sauce can be refrigerated for up to 3 days.)

CREAMY HORSERADISH-MUSTARD SAUCE

Whisk 6 tablespoons mayonnaise, 2 tablespoons horseradish, 1 tablespoon whole-grain mustard, 1 minced garlic clove, ⅛ teaspoon salt, ⅛ teaspoon pepper, and dash hot sauce together. Serve. (Makes ½ cup. Sauce can be refrigerated for up to 3 days.)

HOW TO USE

• Zip up cocktail sauce

• Add flavor to a Bloody Mary

• Mix 2 tablespoons horseradish with ½ cup mayonnaise to make a sandwich spread

PRESERVED LEMONS

PREP 20 minutes

AGE 6 to 8 weeks

YIELD 4 preserved lemons

WHY THIS RECIPE WORKS Preserved lemons are a staple of Moroccan cuisine. Typically the rinds, which become soft and aromatic once preserved, are sliced thin or minced before being added to a recipe. Their bright flavor, balanced by brininess and sourness, can add nuance to all sorts of dishes. We tested both Meyer lemons and common supermarket lemons and found both work; tasters preferred Meyer lemons because they are thin-skinned and mellower. Some recipes we found packed the lemons in a jar with copious amounts of salt. However, we found that creating a cavity in each lemon and filling it with 2 tablespoons of kosher salt was enough to cure the lemons without making them overly salty. We like using kosher salt, rather than table salt, because its large grain size is easier to work with. We placed the lemons in a 1-quart glass jar and poured lemon juice over the top. We stored the lemons in the refrigerator for at least six weeks, shaking the jar once a day for the first few days to ensure even distribution of juice and salt. When the lemons were fully preserved they appeared softened and a bit deflated. Sometimes it took up to eight weeks for the lemons to become fully preserved and ready to use. At that point, we found that rinsing the lemon before using it gave a slightly cleaner flavor, but wasn’t absolutely necessary. Tasters preferred removing the flesh and pith and using just the rind, but you can use all parts of the lemon. Look for Meyer lemons from August through March at higher-end markets. It’s important to wash, scrub, and dry the lemons well before preserving. These lemons cannot be processed for long-term storage.

12 lemons, preferably Meyer

½ cup Diamond Crystal kosher salt

1. Wash and dry 4 lemons, then cut lengthwise into quarters, stopping 1 inch from bottom so lemons stay intact at base. Juice remaining lemons to yield 1½ cups juice; reserve extra juice to use as needed.

2. Working over bowl, gently stretch 1 cut lemon open and pour 2 tablespoons salt into center. Gently rub cut surfaces of lemon together, then place in 1-quart jar. Repeat with remaining cut lemons and salt. Add any accumulated salt and juice in bowl to jar.

3. Pour 1½ cups lemon juice into jar and press gently to submerge lemons. (Add more lemon juice to jar if needed to cover lemons completely.) Cover jar tightly with lid and shake. Refrigerate lemons, shaking jar once per day for first 4 days to redistribute salt and juice. Let lemons cure in refrigerator until glossy and softened, 6 to 8 weeks. (Preserved lemons can be refrigerated for at least 6 months.)

4. To use, cut off desired amount of preserved lemon. If desired, use knife to remove pulp and white pith from rind before using.

HOW TO USE

• Add to tagines, braises, or soups

• Mince and stir into vinaigrettes

• Sprinkle over vegetable or grain salads

• Add to pestos

To help the lemons cure quickly, cut them lengthwise into quarters, stopping 1 inch from the bottom. Gently stretch the lemons open so that they’re easier to work with, being careful not to detach the quarters from the base. Working over a bowl to catch any stray bits of salt or juice, rub the inside of each lemon with 2 tablespoons of kosher salt to help break down the flesh of the lemons.

Place the lemons in a jar and be sure to add any of the salt and juice that has accumulated in the bowl. Cover the lemons with 1½ cups of freshly squeezed lemon juice and press to submerge them completely; add extra juice to cover the lemons if necessary. Refrigerate the lemons, shaking the jar once per day for the first four days.

Cure the lemons in the refrigerator until glossy and softened, six to eight weeks.

APPLESAUCE

PREP 20 minutes

COOK 40 minutes

PROCESS 15–30 minutes

YIELD four 1-pint jars

WHY THIS RECIPE WORKS The joys of homemade applesauce are subtle but persuasive. Compared with store-bought, our homemade applesauce is noticeably fresh, with a deep apple flavor and a thick, supple texture. To us, preserving the taste of fresh apples was paramount. We wanted a pure apple flavor, and we wanted a sauce that was soft, smooth, and thick. Debates raged as to whether to cook the apples with or without their peels. Our test results tipped the scales in favor of including peels. This sauce tasted more complex than skinless sauce, which was one-dimensional. As an added bonus, not needing to peel the apples made this recipe easy and quick to prep. While sauces made from Jonagold, Pink Lady, Jonathan, and Macoun apples boasted the most depth, applesauces made using Golden Delicious, Empire, McIntosh, and Rome apples were all acceptable. Note that the yield of the sauce may vary widely depending on the type of apple and how much of it is trimmed away with the core.

5½ pounds apples, unpeeled, cored, and cut into rough 1-inch pieces

½ cup sugar, plus extra as needed

¼ teaspoon salt

4 cups water

2 cinnamon sticks

1. Set canning rack in large pot, place four 1-pint jars in rack, and add water to cover by 1 inch. Bring to simmer over medium-high heat, then turn off heat and cover to keep hot.

2. Combine apples, sugar, salt, water, and cinnamon in large stockpot. Cover pot and cook over medium-high heat, stirring occasionally, until apples are very tender and beginning to break down, 25 to 35 minutes. Discard cinnamon sticks.

3. Working in batches, process mixture through food mill fitted with medium disk set over large bowl. Return puree to now-empty pot, season with additional sugar to taste, and return to boil; remove from heat.

4. Meanwhile, place dish towel flat on counter. Using jar lifter, remove jars from pot, draining water back into pot. Place jars upside down on towel and let dry for 1 minute. Using funnel and ladle, portion hot sauce into hot jars, leaving ½ inch headspace. Slide wooden skewer along inside of jar to remove air bubbles.

5a. For short-term storage: Let applesauce cool to room temperature, cover, and refrigerate until chilled, about 2 hours. Serve. (Applesauce can be refrigerated for at least 2 months.)

5b. For long-term storage: While jars are hot, wipe rims clean, add lids and screw on rings until fingertip-tight; do not overtighten. Return pot of water with canning rack to boil. Lower jars into water, cover, bring water back to boil, then start timer. Cooking time will depend on your altitude: Boil 15 minutes for up to 1,000 feet, 20 minutes for 1,001 to 3,000 feet, 25 minutes for 3,001 to 6,000 feet, or 30 minutes for 6,001 to 8,000 feet. Turn off heat and let jars sit in pot for 5 minutes. Remove jars from pot and let cool for 24 hours. Remove rings, check seal, and clean rims. (Sealed jars can be stored for up to 1 year.)

DOUBLE IT

Double all ingredients. Batches of applesauce must be cooked and processed in two separate batches. All fruit can be prepped at same time; refrigerate second batch until ready to cook.

Choosing the apples is the most important part of making applesauce; not all apples will make great applesauce. Once washed, the apples need to be stemmed, cored, and cut into 1-inch pieces. The apple skins will add crucial flavor (and sometimes a lovely pink color) to the applesauce, so do not peel the apples.

Once prepped, the apples are simply cooked in a large pot with some sugar and water along with a pinch of salt and some cinnamon sticks for flavor. You will need a sizable pot for this step, as a standard-size Dutch oven will be too small.

The apples don’t require a lot of cooking, and in fact, if you cook them for too long you will actually cook out the apple flavor. You simply want the apples to soften so that they will be easy to process through the food mill.

Using a food mill is the easiest way to turn the cooked apples into applesauce and strain out the skins. Be sure to use the medium disk; smaller disks will turn the applesauce into an overly fine puree, while the large disk will pass chunks of apples through. Be sure to stop and clean the disk of skins every so often, or else they will clog up the holes and eventually pass through the disk in small pieces.

Before processing the applesauce, it is important to bring it back to a boil. As with most canning, the food and the jars must both be hot in order to be safe.

Processing the jars of applesauce is just like processing jars of jam or pickles. Lower the jars into the hot water using a jar lifter, then cover the pot and bring the water to a boil. Once the water is boiling, start the timer and boil the jars as needed given your altitude listed in the recipe.

APPLE BUTTER

PREP 20 minutes

COOK 1½ hours

YIELD two 1-cup jars

WHY THIS RECIPE WORKS Apple butter should be full of real apple flavor, but too often is overspiced and underwhelming. Since apple butter is essentially applesauce cooked long enough for the apples to caramelize into a dark paste, we saw no reason to add an excess of seasonings that would detract from the apples. Instead, we wanted to intensify the apples into a lush butter that needed no embellishments. McIntosh apples are prized for their sweet flavor and provided the perfect backbone, while tart Granny Smiths added complexity. Many recipes we found called for peeling the apples before cooking; however, much of the apples’ flavor is in the skins. By simmering the apples with their skins, not only were we able to extract more flavor, but the apples also softened enough that the flesh separated from the skins when passed through a food mill or mesh strainer. Now it was time to consider the cooking liquid for the apples. Many recipes called for water, but that diluted the flavor. Instead, we used apple cider to reinforce the apple flavor, along with deep, pungent Calvados to bring out earthy sweetness. To sweeten the mixture, we started using granulated sugar, but found that replacing a portion of it with brown sugar added extra depth. After about an hour, the puree had darkened to a rich brown color and thickened enough to leave a solid trail behind the path of a spatula. For safety reasons, be sure to use bottled lemon juice, not fresh-squeezed juice, in this recipe (click here). This apple butter can be processed for long-term storage; click here for the instructions.

1½ pounds McIntosh apples, cored, quartered, and cut into 1-inch pieces

1 pound Granny Smith apples, cored, quartered, and cut into 1-inch pieces

⅔ cup apple cider

⅔ cup Calvados or applejack

½ cup granulated sugar

⅓ cup packed light brown sugar

2 tablespoons bottled lemon juice

¼ teaspoon salt

1. Bring apples, cider, and Calvados to boil in large saucepan over medium-high heat. Reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer, stirring occasionally, until apples are very soft, about 30 minutes.

2. Working in batches, process mixture through food mill fitted with medium disk set over bowl; alternatively, use rubber spatula to work mixture through fine-mesh strainer set over bowl. Return puree to clean saucepan.

3. Stir in granulated sugar, brown sugar, lemon juice, and salt. Cook over low heat, stirring occasionally, until mixture is browned, thickened, and rubber spatula leaves distinct trail when dragged across bottom of pot, 45 minutes to 1 hour.

4. Let apple butter cool slightly. Using funnel and spoon, portion apple butter into two 1-cup jars, then let cool to room temperature. Cover, refrigerate, and serve. (Apple butter can be refrigerated for up to 1 month.)

For a well-rounded flavor, we use two types of apples: sweet McIntosh apples and tart Granny Smith apples. We also found it best to leave the skins on the apples when cooking because they add a deep, hearty flavor to the butter. To help the apples cook quickly, cut them into 1-inch pieces.

Cook the apples until they are very soft. Adding some cider and Calvados to the pot adds necessary moisture to prevent scorching, along with a strong hit of apple flavor. Keep the pot covered so the apples don’t dry out.

It’s important to remove the apple skins and mash the apples smooth. We found it easiest to use a food mill; however, you can substitute a fine-mesh strainer and a rubber spatula if you don’t have a mill. Working in batches, process the cooked apple mixture through the food mill set over bowl.

Now it is time to cook down the pureed apple mixture into a butter with some sugar and seasonings. Be sure to use a clean pot for this step. Combine the pureed apples, granulated sugar, brown sugar, lemon juice, and salt in the clean saucepan.

Cooking down the apple mixture into butter can take up to an hour, and it is important to stir the mixture to prevent it from burning on the pan bottom. Cook the mixture uncovered over low heat, stirring occasionally, until it is browned, thickened, and a rubber spatula leaves a distinct trail when dragged across the bottom of the pot, 45 minutes to 1 hour.

Let the apple butter cool slightly and then portion it into two 1-cup jars. (Cooling the butter before portioning it into the jars protects the jars from cracking.) Once the jarred apple butter has cooled completely, cover the jars tightly, and keep refrigerated. The apple butter should last in the refrigerater for up to 1 month.

SPICED PEAR BUTTER

PREP 20 minutes

COOK 1½ hours

YIELD two 1-cup jars

WHY THIS RECIPE WORKS Pears come to life when cooked down into fragrant, spiced pear butter, but we found that simpler was better when it came to flavoring the mixture. We started with a recipe similar to our apple butter, testing batches with granulated versus brown sugar, pear juice, pear brandy, and apple juice. We also spiced the mixture with a vanilla bean, a cinnamon stick, and some cloves. Each batch was too sweet and the spices completely overwhelmed the pear flavor. We scaled back, making a version with water and cinnamon alone, but this batch was too bland. Next, we swapped 100 percent pear juice for the water, but stayed away from sugar. We also tossed in one star anise pod along with the cinnamon stick for warmth and depth. Tasters were happier with this version, praising its pear flavor and hint of spice. It turned out that sugar had been masking the pear flavor. Up until now, we’d been treating this mixture the same as our apple butter—cooking the cut-up fruit and then passing it through a strainer. However, pear skins break down so much that flecks still ended up in the finished product. Surprisingly, tasters liked this rustic look and we were able to smooth out the puree by processing the cooked fruit in a food processor before cooking it down—no straining necessary. Ripe pears work best here. If your pears are still a little hard they may take longer to soften in step 1. It’s important to use pure pear juice in this recipe; do not use juice blends or juice with added sugar. For safety reasons, be sure to use bottled lemon juice, not fresh-squeezed juice, in this recipe (click here). This pear butter can be processed for long-term storage; click here for the instructions.

3 pounds ripe Bosc or Bartlett pears, halved, cored, and cut into 1-inch pieces

1½ cups pure pear juice

2 tablespoons bottled lemon juice

1 cinnamon stick

1 star anise pod

¼ teaspoon salt

1. Bring pears and pear juice to boil in large saucepan over medium-high heat. Reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer, stirring occasionally, until pears are very soft, about 30 minutes.

2. Transfer mixture to food processor and process until smooth, about 30 seconds. Return puree to clean saucepan.

3. Stir in lemon juice, cinnamon stick, star anise pod, and salt. Cook over low heat, stirring occasionally, until mixture is browned, thickened, and rubber spatula leaves distinct trail when dragged across bottom of pot, 45 minutes to 1 hour.

4. Discard cinnamon stick and star anise pod. Let pear butter cool slightly. Using funnel and spoon, portion pear butter into two 1-cup jars, then let cool to room temperature. Cover, refrigerate, and serve. (Pear butter can be refrigerated for up to 1 month.)

Using well-washed but unpeeled pears, halve, core, and cut them into 1-inch pieces. Cook the pears with the pear juice in a covered pot until they are very soft and can be pureed easily, about 30 minutes.

Transfer the pear mixture to a food processor and process until the mixture is very smooth; the skins should be so soft that they break down into tiny pieces easily.

Cook the pear puree along with some seasonings until it is browned and thickened and a rubber spatula leaves a distinct trail when dragged across the pot bottom; be sure to keep an eye on the pot and reduce the heat if you see any scorching.

Cranberry-Orange Butter

CRANBERRY-ORANGE BUTTER

PREP 10 minutes

COOK 50 minutes

YIELD two 1-cup jars

WHY THIS RECIPE WORKS Tart cranberries, full of natural pectin, don’t take long to cook into a velvety-smooth spread. To keep this recipe quick and simple, we first cooked the cranberries in water until they softened and burst. We gave them a spin in the food processor and passed the mixture through a fine-mesh strainer. Just ½ cup of sugar helped to sweeten and thicken the mixture, while cinnamon and nutmeg gave it warmth. However, tasters found this version of cranberry butter a bit one-dimensional—a little too close to canned cranberry sauce. To complement the cranberry, we replaced the water with orange juice, which added more sweetness as it cooked. This version was much closer to something tasters would want to use as a spread. To enhance the orange flavor we used whole strips of orange zest, which were easy to remove from the finished product so as to not distract from the smooth texture. We also found that ½ teaspoon of salt tempered the tartness of the cranberries and brought out the warm, sweet flavors. This recipe works with fresh or frozen cranberries, but if you use frozen cranberries be sure that there are no added ingredients. Both freshly squeezed and store-bought orange juice will work in this recipe. This cranberry-orange butter can be processed for long-term storage; click here for the instructions.

1½ pounds cranberries

4 (2-inch) strips orange zest plus ¾ cup juice (2 oranges)

½ cup sugar

½ teaspoon ground cinnamon

½ teaspoon ground nutmeg

½ teaspoon salt

1. Bring cranberries and orange juice to boil in large saucepan over medium-high heat. Reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer, stirring occasionally, until cranberries are very soft, about 15 minutes.

2. Transfer mixture to food processor and process until smooth, about 30 seconds. Strain processed mixture through fine-mesh strainer into clean large saucepan, pressing on solids to extract as much liquid as possible.

3. Stir in orange zest, sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt. Cook over low heat, stirring often, until mixture is thickened and rubber spatula leaves distinct trail when dragged across bottom of pot, 15 to 20 minutes.

4. Discard orange zest and let cranberry-orange butter cool slightly. Using funnel and spoon, portion cranberry-orange butter into two 1-cup jars, then let cool to room temperature. Cover, refrigerate, and serve. (Cranberry-orange butter can be refrigerated for up to 1 month.)

HOW TO USE

• Stir into a vinaigrette

• Serve with cheese

• Use as a sandwich spread

• Swirl into a bowl of yogurt or cottage cheese

GUAVA BUTTER

PREP 10 minutes

COOK 1 hour

YIELD two 1-cup jars

WHY THIS RECIPE WORKS Guava butter is a great use for this lesser-known fruit. Although many types of guava will work here, we prefer to use small white or yellow guavas because regardless of how ripe they are they produced the most consistent results. As with apples and pears, we found that the skins of the guava contributed significant flavor, so we simply trimmed off the ends and cut the fruit into chunks. Guavas are full of small rock-like seeds, which we removed by passing the mixture through a fine-mesh strainer. Since we’d liked apple cider in our apple butter, and pear juice in our pear butter, naturally we reached for guava juice. We were disappointed to find that store-bought guava juice often contains high-fructose corn syrup and other additives, which we didn’t want to add to our fresh fruit. Water was too bland, so we turned to 100 percent pure apple juice for its neutral flavor and sweetness. It’s important to use apple juice without any added sugar. For safety reasons, be sure to use bottled lemon juice, not fresh-squeezed juice, in this recipe (click here). This guava butter can be processed for long-term storage; click here for the instructions.

2 pounds ripe white or yellow guavas, trimmed and cut into 1-inch pieces

1½ cups apple juice

2 tablespoons bottled lemon juice

¼ teaspoon salt

¼ cup honey

1. Bring guavas and apple juice to boil in large saucepan over medium-high heat. Reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer, stirring occasionally, until guavas are very soft, 20 to 30 minutes.

2. Working in batches, use rubber spatula to work guava mixture through fine-mesh strainer set over bowl. Return puree to clean saucepan.

3. Stir in lemon juice and salt. Cook over low heat, stirring occasionally, until mixture is thickened and rubber spatula leaves distinct trail when dragged across bottom of pot, about 20 minutes. Stir in honey and cook until thickened and reduced to 2 cups, about 10 minutes.

4. Let guava butter cool slightly. Using funnel and spoon, portion guava butter into two 1-cup jars, then let cool to room temperature. Cover, refrigerate, and serve. (Guava butter can be refrigerated for up to 2 months.)

HOW TO USE

• Serve with cheese

• Spread on toast or scones

• Smear on pancakes or waffles

• Serve with roast pork or duck

• Use as a filling for layer cake

We prefer to use small white or yellow guavas as opposed to the large green variety. Leaving the skins intact for the first round of cooking adds important flavor, but be sure to trim the ends and cut the fruit into 1-inch pieces.

Cook the guavas and apple juice together until the fruit is very soft, 20 to 30 minutes.

Working in batches, use a rubber spatula to work the mixture through a fine-mesh strainer set over a bowl; this step will take a while and some good arm muscle because there are lots of little seeds to work around. Once the mixture is smooth, cook it again, along with some lemon juice and salt, until it has a thick, spreadable texture, about 30 minutes total. Add the honey only during the last 10 minutes of cooking to help preserve its delicate, floral flavor.

Quince Butter

QUINCE BUTTER

PREP 10 minutes

COOK 2½ hours

YIELD two 1-cup jars

WHY THIS RECIPE WORKS A quince looks and tastes like a cross between an apple and a pear. It is astringent and harsh when eaten raw, but becomes floral and fresh when cooked down. Batch after batch of the various quince jams and jellies we rigorously tested were either much too set, had a grainy texture, or were overly sweet and masked the fruit’s flavor. We found that quinces were extremely temperamental to work with, and we set out to create the most foolproof way to take advantage of this autumn fruit’s bounty. Softening the quinces on the stovetop with 3 cups water, before transferring it to a food processor, made it easy to process the quinces into a smooth puree. Passing the puree through a fine-mesh strainer eliminated the hard bits we kept tasting in previous batches. We landed on the addition of a cup of sugar, which slightly muted the characteristically tart quince as well as enhanced its sweetness. Lemon juice lent brightness, freshness, and acidity and highlighted the quince’s floral notes. Cooking down the quince mixture for just 30 minutes transformed it from light yellow to a beautiful rosy hue. For safety reasons, be sure to use bottled lemon juice, not fresh-squeezed juice, in this recipe (click here). This quince butter can be processed for long-term storage; click here for the instructionsw.

3 cups water

1 pound quinces, stemmed, cored, and cut into 1-inch pieces (3 cups)

1 cup sugar

3 tablespoons bottled lemon juice

1. Bring water and quinces to boil in large saucepan over medium-high heat. Reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer, stirring occasionally, until quinces are very soft, about 1 hour.

2. Let mixture cool slightly, then transfer mixture to food processor and process until smooth, about 30 seconds. Working in batches, use rubber spatula to work quince mixture through fine-mesh strainer set over bowl. Return puree to clean saucepan.

3. Stir in sugar and lemon juice and bring to boil over medium-high heat. Reduce heat to medium-low, and cook, stirring often, until mixture is thickened and rubber spatula leaves distinct trail when dragged across bottom of pot, about 30 minutes.

4. Let quince butter cool slightly. Using funnel and spoon, portion quince butter into two 1-cup jars, then let cool to room temperature. Cover, refrigerate, and serve. (Quince butter can be refrigerated for up to 1 month.)

HOW TO USE

• Top a bowl of oatmeal

• Swirl into plain yogurt

• Serve with Manchego cheese

• Use on a ham or turkey sandwich

QUINCE PASTE

PREP 20 minutes

COOK 4–5 hours

YIELD eight ½-cup wide-mouth jars

WHY THIS RECIPE WORKS The floral perfume of quinces belies their astringent and unyielding flesh but they can be transformed into a thick, slightly tart jelly with caramel and sweet apple notes. Quince paste is made by simmering quince pulp with sugar for several hours. We simmered quinces in water until very soft then strained and pureed the fruit and returned it to the pot with some of the cooking liquid, sugar, and lemon juice. To avoid scorching, we transferred the pot to the oven, carefully stirring the caramelized quince until it was deeply colored and thickened. We transferred the hot mixture to parchment paper–lined wide-mouth jars where it set up beautifully. For safety reasons, be sure to use bottled lemon juice, not fresh-squeezed juice, in this recipe (click here). This quince paste cannot be processed for long-term storage.

3½ pounds quinces, quartered and cored

8 cups water

4 cups sugar

¼ cup bottled lemon juice

1. Combine quinces and water in Dutch oven and cover with parchment paper round that has been cut to fit. Bring to boil, then reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer until quinces are very soft and can be easily pierced with knife, 1 to 1½ hours.

2. Adjust oven rack to middle position and heat oven to 350 degrees. Drain quinces through colander set in large bowl. Return cooking liquid to now-empty Dutch oven and boil over medium-high heat until it has reduced to 3 cups, 12 to 15 minutes.

3. Meanwhile, process quinces in food processor until very smooth, about 45 seconds. Working in batches, use rubber spatula to work quince puree through fine-mesh strainer set over bowl, pressing firmly on solids to extract as much puree as possible; discard solids. (You should have about 4 cups puree.)

4. Stir strained quinces, sugar, and lemon juice into reduced cooking liquid. Bring to boil, then reduce heat to medium-low, and simmer, stirring occasionally, until puree darkens and becomes very thick, about 30 minutes.

5. Transfer pot to oven and cook until puree turns dark rusty brown and rubber spatula leaves distinct trail when dragged across bottom of pot, 1½ to 2 hours, stirring and scraping sides of pot every 15 minutes.

6. Meanwhile, cut out 8 parchment paper rounds to line bottom of eight ½-cup wide-mouth jars; set aside. Place dish towel flat on counter. Place jars in large bowl and place under hot running water until heated through, 1 to 2 minutes. Place jars upside down on towel, let dry for 1 minute, then line bottoms with parchment.

7. Using funnel and ladle, portion hot quince paste into hot jars, cool to room temperature, cover, and refrigerate until set, about 4 hours. To serve, run butter knife around inside edge of jar to loosen. Invert jar over plate and shake to unmold. (Quince paste can be refrigerated for up to 6 months.)

HOW TO USE

• Serve with a hard, salty cheese such as Manchego

• Serve with toasted nuts

• Serve with roasted meats

As with most of the fruit butters in this chapter, we prefer to leave the skin on the fruit because it adds valuable flavor and color. You do, however, need to quarter and core the fruit. We found it is easiest to quarter the fruit first, then cut out the seeds; be careful not to cut away too much of the fruit when removing the seeds.

Cook the quinces with 8 cups of water in a covered Dutch oven until they are very soft, 1 to 1½ hours. To help the quinces soften and prevent the water from evaporating during the long cooking time, we found it very helpful to place a piece of parchment on top of the fruit and water.

Carefully pull back parchment being mindful of steam. To test a piece of fruit, poke it with a paring knife. The knife should feel little to no resistance as it cuts through the fruit.

Strain the quinces from the cooking liquid, reserving the liquid. Return the cooking liquid to the now- empty pot and boil until it has reduced to 3 cups, 12 to 15 minutes.

While the cooking liquid reduces, process the cooked quinces in a food processor until very smooth, then work the quince puree through a fine-mesh strainer using a rubber spatula (or a ladle). This not only strains out the skins, but gets rid of the fine, gritty texture that quinces are known for.

Stir the strained quinces, sugar, and lemon juice into the reduced liquid and continue to cook the mixture down to a thick paste. We start this process on the stovetop, but move it into a moderate oven once it becomes thick and prone to scorching. Stirring the mixture often is important, especially as the mixture gets very thick.

CONVERSIONS AND EQUIVALENTS

Some say cooking is a science and an art. We would say that geography has a hand in it, too. Flour milled in the United Kingdom and elsewhere will feel and taste different from flour milled in the United States. So we cannot promise that the loaf of bread you bake in Canada or England will taste the same as a loaf baked in the States, but we can offer guidelines for converting weights and measures. We also recommend that you rely on your instincts when making our recipes and refer to the visual cues provided.

The recipes in this book were developed using standard U.S. measures following U.S. government guidelines. The charts below offer equivalents for U.S. and metric measures All conversions are approximate and have been rounded up or down to the nearest whole number.

EXAMPLE

1 teaspoon = 4.9292 milliliters, rounded up to 5 milliliters

1 ounce = 28.3495 grams, rounded down to 28 grams

VOLUME CONVERSIONS
U.S. METRIC
1 teaspoon 5 milliliters
2 teaspoons 10 milliliters
1 tablespoon 15 milliliters
2 tablespoons 30 milliliters
¼ cup 59 milliliters
⅓ cup 79 milliliters
½ cup 118 milliliters
¾ cup 177 milliliters
1 cup 237 milliliters
1¼ cups 296 milliliters
1½ cups 355 milliliters
2 cups (1 pint) 473 milliliters
2½ cups 591 milliliters
3 cups 710 milliliters
4 cups (1 quart) 0.946 liter
1.06 quarts 1 liter
4 quarts (1 gallon) 3.8 liters
CONVERTING FAHRENHEIT TO CELSIUS
We include temperatures in many of the recipes in this book and we recommend an instant-read thermometer for the job. To convert Fahrenheit degrees to Celsius, use this simple formula:  
Subtract 32 degrees from the Fahrenheit reading, then divide the result by 1.8 to find the Celsius reading.  

EXAMPLE
“If the water climbs above 180 degrees, the pickles will turn mushy.”

TO CONVERT
180°F – 32 = 148°
148° ÷ 1.8 = 82.22°C, rounded down to 82°C

  
WEIGHT CONVERSIONS
OUNCES GRAMS
½ 14
¾ 21
1 28
1½ 43
2 57
2½ 71
3 85
3½ 99
4 113
4½ 128
5 142
6 170
7 198
8 227
9 255
10 283
12 340
16 (1 pound) 454
